user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_close(struct metal_bus *bus,
				  struct metal_device *device)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev);
	metal_list_del(&device->node);
	free(ldev);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_dev_close:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of the standard library function memcmp (or any string comparison of null‑terminated strings) appear in the provided code fragments. The function metal_linux_dev_close only calls a driver callback (ldrv->dev_close), metal_list_del, and free; the shown helpers to_linux_device and to_linux_bus merely perform container-of pointer conversions. None of these fragments contain or imply a memcmp-based comparison of null‑terminated strings. Note: the implementation of ldrv->dev_close is not provided here — if that external callback exists elsewhere in the codebase it should be inspected separately for any use of memcmp on null‑terminated strings, but it is outside the supplied fragments and therefore not included as suspicious here.
